media.credit: CDC/ Alissa Eckert, MS; Dan Higgins, MAM

text.headline: Fact: The principal mechanism of COVID-19 infection is aerosol
text.text: See the Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) mega document: https://tinyurl.com/FAQ-aerosols

media.caption: Red is the index patient. Purple got on the bus 30 minutes after the index patient left.

text.headline: Outbreak: Hunan bus. COVID-19 can travel 'twice as far' (4.5m) and linger 30 minutes
text.text:
Newspaper article: Coronavirus can travel twice as far as official ‘safe distance’ and stay in air for 30 minutes, Chinese study finds. A number of passengers became infected during the four-hour bus journey. One was infected AFTER the index patient got off. There is CCTV on all Chinese inter-city busses, so they knew that the index patient never got out of his seat. Article in SCMP, reported mid-January. Study re-published in September after an initial retraction.

Twitter post and original report (@jmcrookston)

media.caption: Chinese mall

text.headline: Outbreak: Indirect spread at a Chinese mall
text.text: Study: Indirect spread at a Chinese mall. Postulated either fomite in elevator or, you guessed it, aerosol. Article in the EID Journal, reported mid-March. See single post (@jmcrookston).

media.caption: Diagram showing arrangement of restaurant tables and air conditioning airflow at site of outbreak

text.headline: Outbreak in Guangzhou restaurant, circulated by air conditioning
text.text:
Everybody infected at a Chinese restaurant was sitting in the path of the air conditioning.

Reported in the CDC Journal in April as COVID-19 Outbreak Associated with Air Conditioning in Restaurant, Guangzhou, China, 2020. Picture from that article

text.headline: Novel coronavirus can transmit via aerosol: expert
text.text: Zeng Qun, deputy head of Shanghai Civil Affairs Bureau: 'The routes of the novel coronavirus infection include transmission via aerosol', and goes on to say 'residents should take a series of measures including canceling all social activities and gatherings, opening windows regularly to maintain the circulation of indoor air and focusing on household disinfection.'

media.caption: Diagram showing arrangement of infecteds at the call centre, in blue.

text.headline: Outbreak at call centre in Seoul, South Korea
text.text: Outbreak at South Korean call centre in Seoul. Reported in the CDC Journal as Coronavirus Disease Outbreak in Call Center, South Korea in late April as early release. Picture 1, picture 2.

media.caption: Graph shows the spray factor for three emergent coronaviruses

text.headline: Study: Aerosol efficiencies of three emergent coronaviruses (incl SARS-CoV-2)
text.text: "..... We also quantified the long-term persistence of SARS-CoV-2 and its ability to maintain infectivity when suspended in **aerosols** for up to 16 hours."

media.caption: Schlieren Imaging with high speed sensitivity camera recording (10,000 frames/second, courtesy of Bell Labs)

text.headline: This is how we sneeze
text.text: High-speed Video showing a human sneeze

media.caption: Skagit Choir seatmap: infection distance

text.headline: Outbreak: People at Skagit choir practice infected at distance
text.text: Following a 2.5-hour choir practice attended by 61 people, including a symptomatic index patient, 32 confirmed and 20 probable secondary COVID-19 cases occurred (attack rate = 53.3% to 86.7%); three patients were hospitalized, and two died. Transmission was likely facilitated by close proximity (within 6 feet for some) during practice and augmented by the act of singing. Reported in: CDC Journal May 15, 2020 as well as a larger study that was available much later in September. See also a one-slide summary (@jljcolorado)

media.caption: High COVID-19 attack rate at a Church in Arkansas

text.headline: Outbreak: High COVID-19 attack rate at a Church in Arkensas
text.text: Two symptomatic people attended church events March 6-8. From that, 35 or 92 people were infected and 3 died. Reported in the MMWR journal.

media.caption: Droplets hitting the group, aerosols going and going
media.credit: Lidia Morawskaa & Junji Cao vi Elsevier

text.headline: Facing reality
text.text: Study: Airborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2: The world should face the reality - Lidia Morawska and Junji Caob. See also September 2020 study from Morawskaa et al

media.caption: Man sneezing

text.headline: How there is there any debate?
text.text: Simple social media post on Reddit, 'the front page of the internet'. (Source unknown)

media.caption: Generic tug-of-war pic, typical of campers

text.headline: Outbreak: SARS-CoV-2 Transmission and Infection at Overnight Camp in Georgia, USA
text.text: SARS-CoV-2 Transmission and Infection Among Attendees of an Overnight Camp — Georgia, June 2020. 597 Georgia residents attended camp A. Median camper age was 12 years. 344 were tested and 260 (76%) were positive. The overall attack rate was 44% (260 of 597). Reported in MMWR journal in August. See Wired Article too.

media.caption: Clearing the Air Effectively

text.headline: Japanese news - education around mitigating aerosol risk
text.text: Key is ventilation. Japan assumed it was airborne from the very beginning. Hence their mask culture and focus on air flow. Here is how to ventilate a room quickly. See @DrEricDing tweet too.

media.caption: Clip from Japanese video on computer modelling of aerosol nature of Covid-19

text.headline: Japan has long accepted COVID's airborne spread
text.text: Article: "If the WHO recognizes what we did in Japan, then maybe in other parts of the world, they will change (their antiviral procedures)," said Shin-Ichi Tanabe, a professor in the architecture department of Japan's prestigious Waseda University. He was one of the 239 international scientists who co-wrote an open letter to the WHO urging the United Nations agency to revise its guidelines on how to stop the virus spreading

text.headline: Mounting evidence suggests coronavirus is airborne
text.text: 239 scientists signed an open letter to the transnational organization urging it to consider emerging evidence that the virus can be considered airborne and to adjust its guidance accordingly.

media.caption: Snapshots of the droplet-laden cough simulation
media.credit: University of Twente and University of Rome Tor Vergata

text.headline: Airborne transmission
text.text: Study: Long-distance airborne transmission through multiphase turbulent droplet cloud emission is an essential factor

media.caption: Laser-induced fluorescence is a method of using lasers to cause specific substances to emit light
media.credit: By Jan Pavelka/Wikimedia Commons, CC BY-SA

text.headline: Growing body of research
text.text: Article: A growing body of research shows that SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, can spread from person to person through the air. Indoor spaces with poor ventilation in areas where the virus is prevalent are particularly hazardous

media.caption: Generic pic of a Starbucks

text.headline: Outbreak: 56 infected in a Starbucks in South Korea
text.text: Study: 56 coronavirus cases were linked to a Starbucks in South Korea. But employees who were wearing masks didn't get infected. Read More: Business Insider or Fortune.com or CNN

media.caption: Slide from recent NASEM workshop on airborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2

text.headline: Environmental Health Matters Initiative (EHMI) workshop
text.text: Workshop session: Droplets versus aerosols and more for the pandemic. Downloadable PDFs for 19 speakers in the workshop an a video of proceedings.

media.caption: Transmission routes through drains

text.headline: Airborne in apartment building through the drainage system
text.text: Study: Evidence of #Airborne #SARSCoV2 traveling 12 floors of an apt building through the drainage system: 200+ residents in a wing of a high-rise were tested, revealing 9 infections. Those families lived in 3 vertically aligned flats connected by drainage pipes in the bathrooms. See <a href='https://twitter.com/AliNouriPhD/status/1342232561205047301'>@AliNouriPhD thread</>

text.headline: Outbreak: 26 of 27 people in small meeting room infected. One who escaped was masked.
text.text:
26 of 27 people in a small meeting room catch it. The one who escaped was masked.
News report in Korean.
Twitter thread.
QUOTE: On the 29th of last month, 26 out of 27 people who attended the'Congchunghacho briefing session' held in a building in Buk-gu, Daegu, were confirmed as a new coronavirus infection (Corona 19). The infection rate is a whopping 97%. Most of them were in their 50s to 80s and gathered from all over the country, including Daegu, Gyeongbuk, Gyeongnam, and Chungbuk. After contact with them, the infection spread to each area.

Jeong Mo (63, Sangju, Gyeongbuk) was the only person who avoided infection even after attending the briefing session...People sat close together in a narrow space of about 100m² with poor ventilation.

media.caption: Diagram of room with the depiction of patient bed and air sampler locations

text.headline: Air sampled from room of COVID-19 patients had the virus-laden aerosols
text.text:
Viable (infectious) SARS-CoV-2 was present in aerosols within the hospital room of COVID-19 patients.

Airborne virus was detected in the absence of healthcare aerosol-generating procedures.

The virus strain detected in the aerosols matched with the virus strain isolated from a patient with acute COVID-19.

media.caption: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Director Dr. Robert Redfield puts his mask back on after speaking at a Senate Appropriations subcommittee hearing

text.headline: CDC changes, then retracts, web posting on how virus spreads
text.text:
Article: The top U.S. public health agency stirred confusion by posting — and then taking down — an apparent change in its position [to aerosols] on how easily the coronavirus can spread from person to person through the air.
But officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention say their position has not really changed ...

media.caption: Adolescent with COVID-19 as the Source of an Outbreak at a 3-Week Family Gathering — Four States, June–July 2020

text.headline: Outbreak: Adolescent with COVID-19 Source of Outbreak at 3-Week Family Gathering
text.text: Adolescent with COVID-19 as the Source of an Outbreak at a 3-Week Family Gathering — Four States, June–July 2020. Adolescent was source of outbreak. Family members who visited the house but stayed outdoors were not infected. Link to Twitter thread

media.caption: After four hours without safety measures

text.headline: how the coronavirus is spread through the air
text.text: Article: The risk of contagion is highest in indoor spaces but can be reduced by applying all available measures to combat infection via aerosols. Here is an overview of the likelihood of infection in three everyday scenarios, based on the safety measures used and the length of exposure.

text.headline: Infectious Drops and Aerosols: A MIAEH seminar by Dr. Don Milton
text.text: Dr. Don Milton, professor of applied environmental health at the University of Maryland, gave a seminar about infectious aerosols and their role in the spread of viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. He is Principal Investigator of the UMD StopCOVID study which is examining how much airborne virus an a person infected with Covid-19 exhales

media.caption: Still from JAMA Network conversation

text.headline: New head of US CDC acknowledges aerosol nature of COVID-19
text.text: “...aerosols, I think, was another surprise. We thought we knew how respiratory viruses generally work. We thought it was going to be droplet, and it turns out, you know, a lot of aerosol.” - Rochelle Walensky

media.caption: Infected donor ferret below with a healthy indirect recipient ferret above

text.headline: Study shows aerosol spread between ferrets
text.text: Article: Elaborate apparatus shows the virus spreads via aerosolized particles between ferrets more than a meter apart. Linsey Marr: “If I were someone who thought that large droplets were the way [that SARS-CoV-2 was transmitted] and if I were skeptical about aerosols, this study might make me rethink my assumptions,”

media.caption: CBS news feed pic

text.headline: Canada acknowledges aerosol transmission
text.text:
Official Guidance: "SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, spreads from an infected person to others through respiratory droplets and aerosols created when an infected person coughs, sneezes, sings, shouts, or talks," the updated guidance said.

"The droplets vary in size from large droplets that fall to the ground rapidly (within seconds or minutes) near the infected person, to smaller droplets, sometimes called aerosols, which linger in the air under some circumstances."

media.caption: After only 5 minutes sitting in proximity to spreader, a diner was infected 21 feet away

text.headline: Outbreak: Infected in direct air flow in a Korean restaurant
text.text: Study conclusion: Droplet transmission can occur at a distance greater than 2 m if there is direct air flow from an infected person. Therefore, updated guidelines involving prevention, contact tracing, and quarantine for COVID-19 are required for control of this highly contagious disease. A post linking to another post about this event: post 1 (@jmcrookston).

media.caption: Wells curves modified by accounting for droplet cloud aerodynamics, thermodynamics, and droplet desiccation
media.credit: Diagram from Chaudhuri, Basu & Saha's study

text.headline: Analyzing the dominant SARS-CoV-2 transmission routes
text.text: Study excerpt: At typical, air-conditioned yet quiescent indoor space, for average viral loading, cough droplets of initial diameter between 10 µm and 50 µm are found to have the highest infection probability. However, by the time they are inhaled, the diameters reduce to about 1/6th of their initial diameters

media.caption: box fan pic

text.headline: Ventilation in Buildings: CDC recommendation
text.text: CDC now recommends good ventilation for buildings: increasing outdoor air, better filtration, importance of system maintenance, HEPA portable air cleaners, and Ultraviolet Germicidal Irradiation (UVGI) Air Purifiers

media.caption: Structure of the apartment building where the infection outbreaks occurred in two vertical line

text.headline: Airborne Transmission through Apartment Air Ducts
text.text: Possible #Airborne #SARSCoV2 Transmission through Air Ducts (August): after a series of infections, all 437 residents of an apt building were tested. 10 infections uncovered, all living on different floors but along two vertical lines with openings through their bathrooms. See also <a href='https://twitter.com/AliNouriPhD/status/1341193351014572032'>Twitter thread by (@AliNouriPhD)

media.caption: Location of outbreak - restuarant in Melbourne

text.headline: Article: Indoor dining super-spread
text.text: Eleven of the 37 patrons who dined at the Smile Buffalo Thai restaurant on the night of December 21 tested positive to the virus, after visiting between 7pm & 9.30pm Via <a href='https://twitter.com/Orla_Hegarty/status/1347879426957172737'>@Orla_Hegarty tweet

text.headline: Aerosol spread in Chinese department store
text.text: Aerosol transmission, an indispensable route of COVID-19 spread: case study of a department-store cluster (back in Jan 2020). See tweet by @AliNouriPhD

text.headline: Fluid dynamics of COVID-19 airborne infection suggests urgent data for a scientific design of social distancing
text.text: Our results show that a single rule [like 6 feet] for social distancing may not be adequate to protect individuals in different environments. <a href='https://twitter.com/EricTopol/status/1344297867578548225'>Twitter thread by (@EricTopol)
